newsitem.title: UK: BT blocks calls in prostitution crackdown.
newsitem.headline: BT blocks calls in prostitution crackdown.

text.p: British Telecommunications Plc said on Thursday it had started blocking incoming calls to some telephone lines in a crackdown on the thousands of cards advertising prostitution that often litter telephone boxes.

Since an August joint initiative with Westminster council, supported by other telephone companies and the industry regulator Oftel, BT has collected and processed 44,000 cards, most of which advertise prostitution.
So far, it has sent out 150 warning letters.
BT said it would now restrict access to telephone numbers that were illegally advertised.
"Customers whose numbers are persistently found in kiosks are given two written warnings before incoming calls are blocked," BT said in a statement.

While explicit and graphic prostitution adverts tended to amass inside telephone boxes almost exclusively in central London, Brighton and Hove, BT said it planned to take action against all illegal advertising.
BT's contractors clean telephone boxes six days a week and remove 150,000 prostitution adverts from central London and 20,000 from Brighton and Hove, the company noted.

Because of a possible intimidation by "carders", or "vice carders", as the police call them -- those who stick cards into telephone boxes on behalf of prostitutes -- security guards collect adverts in central London.

BT said it expected people to switch networks or look for loopholes. But it added: "We believe that if we stop incoming calls to the numbers advertised, then it becomes pointless to advertise in this way."
